project.title: North Texas Topic Analysis
project.description:
This page demonstrates a topic-coded interview from North Texas, conducted by a student at UT Austin in the context of the Home To Texas program. Questions in this interview centered on change in the community over the decades, the community's sense of identity, and the participants' own biographies and experience. Near the end, a reading passage is included. 
Topic coding was applied for this set of nine topics: 
1.
Change
Aspects of community life that have transformed (culture, economy, demographics).
2.
Identity
Statements defining "who we are" or "who they are" (culture, ethnicity, history, place-based).
3.
Diversity
Direct discussion of the community's ethnic or cultural composition.
4.
Future
Statements, worried or optimistic, about what will happen next for the self or the community.
5.
Sense of Place
Descriptions of the community's physical qualities, local atmosphere, or unique character/feeling.
6.
Livelihood & Economy
Discussion of the current state of work, industry, and financial well-being (jobs, wages, cost of living).
7.
Local Governance
Discussion of the quality and function of civic institutions, leaders, and administration (e.g., elected officials, city council).
8.
Infrastructure & Services
Discussion of specific physical systems and tangible services (e.g., roads, water, power grid, schools, traffic, internet).
9.
Generational Relations
Discussion of relationships, values, or conflicts between different age cohorts (young vs. old).
project.creator: speaktexan
project.authors: Lars Hinrichs, Baylee Ross, Sydney Quant, Jennifer Smith

tags.tag: Participant, Sense of Place, Livelihood & Economy
